ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I think the course load was a little too heavy for this class. In grad school, one expects to be able to let some classes "sit on the back burner" a bit one week to focus on others, and vice versa. However, almost every week I had to focus on this class in some respect from October onward. Readings weren't spaced out well (sometimes readings were really heavy for a class, other times very sparse). I don't think that there should be as many midterms, or if there are still midterms in the future, I would make the final noncumulative. A cumulative final AND a 15 page paper is a lot for one class, in addition to heavy readings and two midterms.
Good overview of wetlands and challenges surrounding them both historically and currently. Kealoha is extremely nice and responsive to students.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The topics were well-covered. Readings were applicable. I also liked the balance between discussion and lecture.
I liked the breadth of discussion in this class.
Opportunity for field trips which were optional. A chance to explore a topic of your interest through a paper. The textbook was enjoyable and not too dense.
The fieldtrips were very useful as well as the book we used throughout the semester.
The readings were the best aspect of the class and I enjoyed the relevant "in the news" stories about wetlands in the news.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Sometimes class discussions were painful.

Need better ways to get class engaged. Maybe take turns finding wetlands in the news and share what you found with class. Maybe students can share what they learned from their papers (informally, not necessarily a full presentation).

Even though this was designed to be a discussion class, we relied a lot on readings alone. It would be great to have organized more fieldtrips and/or assignments that'd foster discussion aside from readings.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: See Question 15.

Perhaps discussion was lacking because of the nature of the papers we discussed (mostly scientific). Maybe we could have focused discussion around other materials that are more relatable and have some human aspect (ex. the wetlands in Louisiana that are sinking).
There was no lab section
The course lectures fit in well with the discussions.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: As a civil engineer, i learned a lot about wetlands and how they can help to offset impacts of development and the impacts of climate change. My interests are in coastal resiliency and will surely find this class useful in my career.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To learn more about the science behind wetland regulation.
To have a better overall understanding of wetlands and how to manage them.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes- I feel like I have a general understanding of many different components of wetlands.
Yes--I feel that I now have a great understanding of wetland science.
Yes!
Yes.
Yes, I am satisfied with what I've learned
Yes, I felt as though I learned more than I expected to actually.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Many times people didn't read, so it was hard to have discussions.
I found group studying helpful for the exams.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Start your paper EARLY and stay on top of readings!
Provides a good overview of wetlands, the problems they are facing, and the challenges of managing them. The course is a little lighter on the workload which makes it enjoyable and less stressful.
Be prepared to write a literature review!
